p: The first attempt to transform S. indicum using Agrobacterium tumefaciens was undertaken in 1999 [ 438] but the difficulty of regenerating sesame plants from callus hampered progress in the field. Careful selection of accessions amenable to transformation and the optimization of regeneration conditions eventually allowed for the development of a reliable transformation protocols with an acceptable transformation efficiency [ 439, 440, 441]. A successful particle bombardment protocol for sesame was also developed [ 442]. Genetic transformation of sesame is therefore accessible.
